comments.commentBody:
This thread makes me impatient.

Sorry, folks, but it is silly to imagine that communication of any sort on the Internet can be kept secret. Law or no law, any government, corporation, or determined hacker can find out anything about anybody. And Wikileaks has shown that we can find out about them. Rather than mouth platitudes about illusory secrecy, let us consider how we shall live in a truly open society. The global village is in fact a small town.
Welcome to China, folks.
At least Rangel had the foresight to vote against the Iraq War.

So living in the South means one is a Christian. Hmm. And being a Christian means one has to vote a certain way. Hmm.

Given that you are "disgusted" by what the guy you voted for has done (the fact that he demonstrably cheated on his spouse and demonstrably lied about it) and you couldn't POSSIBLY vote for someone who actually espouses ideals of kindness, liberty and equality, do you think ANYONE cares about your self-gratifying belief that "South Carolinians are not bad people"?

Nobody much thinks that aside from nut cases in your state or elsewhere. Most people are pretty tolerant of others, no matter how infuriating their seemingly core beliefs seem.

I would submit: Nobody but people you engage in ranting contests with cares.

Chill out, enjoy the triumph of Sanford, and try to clear your head, for Christ's sake.
No, Sanford wasn't condemned for his infidelity. He was deservedly condemned for abandoning his state while in office and lying about it. Governors, even Republicans, aren't supposed to go AWOL.

This should be done anyway. Retired Army generals collect annual pensions north of $150,000, many of $220,000. Yes, annually - out of taxpayers' pockets. These are the most over-rated people in the universe. Start with adjusting their expectations of huge benefit packages after years of mostly sitting on their backsides and pontificating. Think David Petraeus, Stanley McChrystal and John Allen, for starters.

This is actually a reply to the reply below: what well-known consequences? If it's "well-known" that our military, an institution we hold in such reverence because it's steeped in "honor," is full of people who can't even be trusted to afford their peers some basic human respect and dignity, then we have a big problem. Sure, let's throw up our hands and say, "Well of course the guys with all the guns and bombs have no moral fiber whatsoever...How, or why, would you expect them to act responsibly?!" Only good can come of that, obviously.
Slash the Pentagon's budget until the commanding officers learn leadership and obedience.
Money talks. Slash the Pentagon's budget until they learn to control themselves.

Bravo. Brought a tear to the eye for this aging gardener. Must be getting soft. I do miss those Huckleberries I ate when living in the Poconos.

Anyway, my garlic is up over two feet now; from last year. Onions are going nuts; beyond the green onion stage already. Will be picking peas tomorrow. Best I've had in years. Plants are over 3 feet tall and are loaded. Oh well, I will make the neighbors happy and my fingers green. Old Vera next door will be in heaven. Oh the joys of gardening..

Great piece-  I am on the opposite coast, but my now 92-year-old father taught me man of the same things. While I grow a great food garden and fruit trees,  I have not done as good a job with my own kids, but it is not too late to start.

I know just what you mean. We have an azalea, double lavender, that my Polish grandma got as an off-shoot from 'the garden of a murderer'. It's actually a second or third generation start, passing through my mother.

This was a beautiful essay, and a wonderful tribute to your dad. Thank you.
A very beautiful remembrance, straight from the heart and the soil, which are pretty much one and the same.
We learned it from the right.
And is completely justified.

Excuse me? The left is critical of a politician who cheated on his wife, lied about, used taxpayer money to carry out the affair and resigned from office in disgrace and this bothers you somehow? WKO - we both know the extreme hatred here in Alabama for President Obama that is based on racism and lies. You pobably believe that the President is a secret muslim born in Kenya (or is it Indonesia?)  Do liberal democrats run for office claiming they are the party of family values and morality? It's called hypocracy, sir, that's what we can't stomach. Personally I could care less if Samford cheated on his wife - but he did say President Clinton was unfit for office for doing something similar. That's the epitome of hypocracy.
Wow! The vitriol on the left knows no bounds.

Asteroid,

You're spot on. Whoever this new climate-change denier "JohnB" of Scotland is — probably an avatar of wmar's — he needs to see what you've been writing over the years before he can pretend lecture you on what's needed to be taken seriously.

You and I disagree strongly on the solutions — as you know, I am opposed to nuclear energy. But the problem is clear to anyone who is not into denial. Unfortunately, that apparently no longer includes Andy Revkin. (Please see my post below on that topic — and, just below that, my response to the "missing heat" nonsense the deniers have been pushing of late.)
Tell that to Congresswoman Tammy Duckworth who lost both legs fighting in Iraq.
Really?  Couldn't that be said about every work place?  What percentage of soldiers are actually fighting a war? You are stuck in the 1950s.

@Donald Seekins: Your comments stretch so far beyond naive as to be incredible. First, you equate soldiers to being no more than robots, once trained they lose all ability to act in a mature social manner - rubbish. Secondly, you place women in some sort of placid, eden-like world where they are safe and secure, blithely going about their world with no cares - again, rubbish. Thirdly, you seem to have this perverted idea that men, once they are "mixed" with women, become uncontrollable and, much worse, unaccountable, animals. What fantasy world do you live in? Any men who act in this manner are known in the civilian world as criminals - it is far past time that the myopic and outdated military acts in the same manner.

And it is time that men in our society stand up and behave like mature and respectable individuals, not pigs. This comes from someone who is both male and ex-military....there are times when I am regrettably appalled by both.

Although I agree that military personnel who commit rape or sexual harassment should be severely punished, it seems to me that opening up the US armed forces to large numbers of women - even serving in combat - has created a rather unnatural situation. With very few exceptions, armies have historically been the domain of men, trained to do violent things when ordered to do so by their superiors. In a stable, civilized society, women live in a different, generally more peaceful domain, on the "home front." This has been the case in societies as diverse as ancient Rome, medieval Japan and the nation-states of modern Europe and North America.

The recent epidemic of military sexual assaults is far from surprising. Mixing men and women together in our armed forces and expecting the men to be gentlemen strikes me as hopelessly naive, given their training in the arts of violence. After all, as the civilian women of all too many countries know, "rapist" and "soldier" are virtually synonymous.

It might be a good idea if we Americans stopped looking at Hollywood films and realized what fighting a war is really about. It's not a spectator sport.
Or Bill Clinton.
South Carolinians may no longer laugh at Marion Barry.
That does not take away from the fact that New York TImes commenters, about 99.9% are hypocrites regarding their views on the  Clinton affairs compared to the Sanford affairs.

So, the Obama Administration now leaks that it's "on the verge" of allowing the FBI to i-Spy. Translation: some DOJ hacks have just written a memo retroactively giving legal cover to some already-standard government practices. And this article is the White House's way of demonstrating how transparent Obama will be (unlike Bush the Worser) as our civil rights go down the tubes and he gives retroactive immunity to the spies who love us.

I think we figured out the FBI was already peeking anyway, when they managed to glom onto the private emails of David Petraeus.
Hey. Golden retrievers are loyal; they wouldn't go run off with somebody else.They're also pretty smart, so it might be hard to find one that would admit to being a Republican.
I just proves the old adage,  "Politicians are like baby diapers - both need frequent changing.... for the same reason."

This election was a referendum on Obama, plain and simple.  There's nothing wrong with the people in this state.  They just disagree with Obama and his left-wing policies.  I would have preferred that another republican had won the primary, but the bottom line is that nobody wanted another democrat vote in the house for Obama.

The real story of Sanford's win may prove to be Colbert Busch's repeated - and often unsolicited - efforts to distance herself from President Obama. The effort spent courting disaffected Republicans may have backfired by alienating some. Obama's election was the most significant political event many Democrats in SC have ever participated in. Among many SC black voters, where victories have been few, Obama's presidency is iconic in the same way JFK was for my Irish relatives of another generation. It is hard to believe that Colbert Busch's vigorous repudiation of him went unnoticed or without a sapping effect. And that is a shame for this state. I won't play the race card, but only because there isn't a deck big enough to do justice to the way the game is played in this state.

You are correct. That also goes for what, in many National elections, is a clear majority of the electorate. The results over the past two generations are clear: we live in a deeply divided Country
Anyone, especially the pundits, who believes that the R's are half dead or in difficulty, ignores history. The next Congress and Presidential electee will be solidly Republican
Well said.
That's how it was in my former congressional district in Iowa. Lucky us, our former "congressman" got himself gerryed out of our hair.
Only if Jesus was on the ballot as a Democrat.
Big deal: if the surviving Tsarnaev brother ran as a Republican he, too, could win in South Carolina. (On the other hand if Jesus ran under a pseudonym he'd be defeated in a landslide.)
They've also lost any claim that they believe in "family values".

Ummm...you know that Sanford voted to impeach Clinton, right? As far as the Republican party not being the party of stupid, that doesn't really seem to be working out. It also isn't really working out being the "family values" party, unless  your family values include adultery and lying.

Unfortunately this is just one more example of how, "We the people", can be sold just about anything. This is not a political party issue. It is an issue of being an informed electorate. I ask you all ... when are we going to wake up and stop allowing our elected officials to be liars, cheaters and thieves? We have allowed it to happen by being complacent, cowardly and ignorant. The next time you buy something, whether it be a tube of toothpaste or a congressman, ask yourself why you picked it and who sold it too you.

Well, you kinda gotta go to SC, spend time there and get to know some of those people. It's extremely scary. Extremely. I'm a North Carolina native, and somehow our rednecks weren't ever as bad or as numerous as their rednecks. Charleston is a gem of a town, but the majority of people in SC are just plain scary. Seriously though, there is a huge African American population who simply does not turn out to vote, especially in elections like this, and that's inevitably what loses it again and again, for the Democrats.

Totally. What they are saying is that they would rather see their public officials spend state funds on having affairs and covering them up than on the public well-being and improvements to the state.

OK, fine. The people have spoken. That's what's great about the USA- you get to vote and then watch the consequences of your choice. Of course they've made their state a staple of late-night talk shows. Jay Leno must be drooling over this one.

But he found Jesus and god forgave him.
Chuckle chuckle,

Wait a second-he used state travel funds to go see his mistress in South America and people in S Carolina voted for him because they do not like the way Democrats spend gov't money?

Huh?
